summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies and Applications Office, requesting scanning and automation assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He attempted to sell an address book containing names and telephone numbers of potential underage victims of Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the employer of Alfredo Rodriguez and the central figure in a child prostitution case. The address book in Rodriguez's possession is believed to contain information about his underage victims.

persons.name: William T. Murphy
persons.context: Addressed in the routing of the internal FBI request form regarding the scanning of telephone records for the Rodriguez/Epstein investigation.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler for Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's underage victims and attempted to sell it, obstructing justice in Epstein's case.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: The Miami Division of the FBI opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: FBI requests scanning of telephone records
events.description: The FBI Miami Division formally requests the Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and automate telephone records related to the Alfredo Rodriguez obstruction case for incorporation into the Telephone Application (TA) database.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case for attempting to sell an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional, previously unknown underage victims of Epstein.
The FBI was processing telephone records (target number 310-435-4725) from the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims.
The document is an internal FBI workflow request (Baleen Sweep) to digitize and analyze these records for the ongoing investigation.
The address book came into Rodriguez's possession during his employment with Epstein, and he attempted to sell it to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of complying with federal subpoenas.
The records were considered unclassified, and the scanning process involved handling both evidentiary and non-evidentiary material with specific security protocols.
